4.11.18  9:56 pm   I wish more songs did what you did in la de da during the end of the chorus, mixing up the progression of the chords and adding a nice twist is there a specific name for this technique?

     i call that a 'duck' because ducks have a head, which is a very special thing that is only at one end. this is actually very common in music but it might have fallen slightly out of use in the age of computers, because it has become technologically easier to just loop the same chords forever, which has its advantages, but that in turn gives you and me an advantage if we do so choose to impliment duckification

4.11.18  9:54 pm   You say to get better at the piano one should spend more time with it, but I'm really interested in playing chords, and naming them, is there any strategy you use when remembering how to name them?

     i've just been familiar with them for so long i don't have a strategy. but i will teach you one to get you started, forgive me if you already know this one, and if you do i will tell you the next one. but the chord is called C major, or just "C" for short. and it is when you play the notes C, E, and G, at the same time, somewhere in the middle range of the keyboard (it doesn't count if you play all 3 notes in the bass range, that is just called mud. if there are any notes in the bass range it should be just 1 and it should be the C note.) so again this is called C major, or "C" for short. if middle C is on the bottom, that's fine. if middle C is in the middle, with G under it and E above it, that is fine (there might also be C in the bass range as well). it might be middle C on top, with G and E right under it (that is probably about as low as you might go for the C chord). it could be higher, with E330(hz) then G and C above it. all these combinations are still called C, or C major. (C as a chord automatically means C major.) I hope that is enough to get you started, forgive me if you already knew all that. if you want to know more i will tell you

4.11.18  9:37 pm   I've always had bad allergies, so I unconsciously learned to speak and sing with a tone that is sort of the opposite of nasal. Not really in the back of my throat, but thick. It sounds good in a narrow range of pitch and type of song, but kind of weak or strained easily outside of that comfort zone. How can I learn to sing more diversely? Assume my sinuses aren't blocked while I'm learning. Thanks!

     if you sing more often you automatically get better in every way. it's like magic

4.11.18  9:25 pm   What is your opinion on songs that flow near seamlessly into each other, as seen in the albums The Dark Side of the Moon and Nonagon Infinity?

     seems legit

     some times you wanna just go in there and blur the hell out of some motion

4.11.18  8:25 pm   What do you think about auto-tune?

     it is useful

      Is it being misused?

     i think it's supposed to put things in tune so maybe someone is using it to trim their hedges? that would be a mis use but i am not sure if anyone is doing that, i have not been keeping tabs on that lately

     sure

4.11.18  3:46 am   what do you have to say about the statement "my  goodness a sentient bowl of pears"

4.11.18  3:22 am   If you're making something, it's it better to frequently keep people updated on your progress

     maybe but that sounds annoying and boring to me, for some reason

     and maybe even give a planned release date

     that can be a speed boost but devastatingly humiliating if it fails

     or just work on the thing silently without telling anyone you're working on anything and then release it when you're done?

     i guess that works

4.11.18  1:12 am   What makes a song interesting to listen to and what do you put into your songs to make sure they're interesting?

     it's all a huge game paradox. for example, if cinder blocks are interesting, and that is what it says in the rule book next to 'interesting,' well guess what just became interesting, that's right it's non cinder blocks

4.11.18  12:57 am   Is there a proper order to learning how to make music?

     no

     can you learn all the advanced stuff first and learn the easy stuff later?

     what is sometimes the most advanced is the things you already knew before you ever picked up an instrument. then later you will have to go back and re-familiarize with those things, perhaps on a long walk through the jungle, for example

4.11.18  12:47 am   people can be blue and that means that they're sad but what about when they're yellow or beige? what do those mean

     perhaps they are an aged super nintendo console
